title: How to Make Lemon Icing

steps.headline: Cream the butter until it turns light and fluffy.
steps.description: Put the butter into a mixing bowl, and beat it with a handheld mixer. If you have a food processor with a whisk attachment, use that instead.

steps.headline: Mix in the lemon juice, vanilla extract, and lemon zest.
steps.description: If you'd like a smoother frosting, omit the lemon zest. If you'd like a less sweet frosting, omit the vanilla extract.

steps.headline: Beat in the sugar gradually, 1 cup (125 grams) at a time.
steps.description: Use medium speed, and keep beating until the mixture becomes smooth. From time to time, scrape the sides of the bowl so that everything mixes evenly.

steps.headline: Add more sugar or lemon juice, if necessary.
steps.description: If the frosting is too dry, add a little more lemon juice or milk. If the frosting is too wet/runny, add a little more sugar. At this point, you can also add a few drops of yellow food coloring to make your frosting more lemon-colored.

steps.headline: Use the frosting on cakes, cupcakes, or as a filling in pastries.
steps.description: If you won't be using the icing for a while, keep it covered with a damp cloth in the fridge, and re-whip it before you spread it. If it is too dry, then add a little more lemon juice or milk.

steps.headline: Add the ingredients into a glass, heat-safe bowl.
steps.description: You can add the lemon zest for a little extra texture, or omit it entirely. You will be heating the ingredients in a microwave.

steps.headline: Put the bowl into a microwave, and heat for 45 seconds or until the butter is melted.
steps.description: Depending on the strength of your microwave, you may need a little more/less cooking time. Keep an eye on the butter.

steps.headline: Take the bowl out and mix the ingredients with a whisk.
steps.description: Keep mixing until there are no lumps or clumps. You want everything to be smooth.

steps.headline: Let the mixture cool for a few minutes.
steps.description: During this time, it will thicken. It will ooze over your pastries, as opposed to sinking into it. If the mixture is too thin, then mix in a little more sugar.

steps.headline: Pour the mixture over your cake or pastry.
steps.description: It is perfect for scones, buns, cakes, and loaves, especially lemon or lavender-flavored ones!

tyn: Hand-held mixer or food processor with a whisk attachment
